Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back simply modelled with single lines marking prothorax and elytra, much distorted, and humeral callosities indicated; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside decorated with a "feathered crown" motif consisting of two Maat feathers either side of central leaf shape with sun-disc underneath; motif possibly stamped; pierced longitudinally; hard glaze pale greenish blue in colour; hard and whitish core; chipped in various places.
Curator's comments: The "feathered crown" is a rather popular motif on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, subtype A173-176, especially A173 for this piece). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 120)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 98-99, Type XXVIII A173)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.087) (phase 3)
